title: 114_hr3484
content: The Act titled "Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016" authorizes certain leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes of providing supportive housing to veterans and their families. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes of providing supportive housing to veterans and their families. Leases can also be made for up to 50 years to third parties for services benefiting veterans and their families, including health promotion, education, vocational training, and recreational activities. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes of providing supportive housing to veterans and their families. Leases can also be made for up to 10 years to The Regents of the University of California for various services benefiting veterans, including employment training, peer activities, legal assistance, volunteerism, family support services, transportation, and more. A lease of real property for up to 10 years to The Regents of the University of California, on behalf of its UCLA campus, with a focus on providing services to veterans. The lease must align with the master plan and prioritize activities benefiting veterans. The Regents at the Campus will focus on providing services to veterans during the lease term, and will also offer additional services and support to benefit veterans as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The Regents at the Campus will provide services to veterans and their families, focusing on activities related to medical, clinical, therapeutic, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling needs. The Regents at the Campus will provide services to veterans and their families, including medical, clinical, therapeutic, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling needs. The Regents must maintain records of additional services provided and make them available to the Secretary. The Secretary is limited in carrying out land-sharing agreements. The Secretary is limited in carrying out land-sharing agreements at the Campus unless they provide additional health-care resources and benefits to veterans and their families. Revenues from leases at the Campus must be credited to the Department medical facilities account. The Secretary must credit revenues from leases at the Campus to the Department medical facilities account for renovation and maintenance purposes. The Secretary is authorized to grant easements on the Campus for public transportation purposes. The Secretary may grant easements on the Campus for public transportation purposes to local or regional public transportation authorities and the State of California, County of Los Angeles, City of Los Angeles, or public utility companies. The Secretary may grant easements on the Campus for public transportation purposes to local or regional public transportation authorities, the State of California, County of Los Angeles, City of Los Angeles, or public utility companies, including those providing electricity, gas, water, sewage, or telecommunication services to the public. Improvements proposed under the easement or right-of-way shall be subject to the Secretary's terms and conditions, and any authorized easement or right-of-way shall be terminated upon abandonment. The Secretary may grant easements on the Campus for public transportation purposes to local or regional public transportation authorities, the State of California, County of Los Angeles, City of Los Angeles, or public utility companies. Any authorized easement or right-of-way shall be terminated upon abandonment, and the land covered shall revert to the United States. The Secretary is prohibited from selling or conveying fee simple title to any real property or improvements at the Campus. The Secretary must ensure consistency with the Master Plan. The Secretary may grant easements on the Campus for public transportation purposes. Any authorized easement shall be terminated upon abandonment. The Secretary is prohibited from selling fee simple title to any real property at the Campus. Each lease must be consistent with the approved master plan. Compliance with Federal laws relating to leases and land use is required. The Secretary must comply with Federal laws regarding leases and land use at the Campus before entering into any new lease or land-sharing agreement. Certification to relevant committees is required before renewing non-compliant agreements. The Committee on Veterans' Affairs must ensure that all recommendations from audit reports are implemented. Leases must comply with federal laws on environmental and historic preservation. A Community Veterans Engagement Board is established. The Secretary must establish a Community Veterans Engagement Board within 180 days to coordinate with the Department of Veterans Affairs and improve services for veterans. The Community Veterans Engagement Board will identify community goals, provide advice to improve services for veterans, and have at least 50% veteran members. The Community Veterans Engagement Board shall include family members of veterans, veteran advocates, service providers, or stakeholders. They will collaborate with the community through public forums and focus on local issues related to health care, benefits, and memorial services at the Campus. Notification and reports are required. The Secretary must notify relevant committees and representatives about lease agreements at the Campus. The Secretary must inform committees and representatives about lease agreements at the Campus, not later than 45 days before entering into or renewing them. Additionally, an annual report must be submitted to relevant committees and representatives one year after the enactment of this Act and annually thereafter. The Senator or Representative representing the Campus area must provide an annual report on all leases and land-sharing agreements at the Campus, evaluating revenue management and specific records. Additionally, the Inspector General must submit reports two and five years after the Act's enactment, as needed. The Inspector General will submit a report on all leases at the Campus to the relevant committees and representatives every two and five years after the Act's enactment. The Inspector General will submit a report on all leases and land management at the Campus, including efforts to implement the master plan. The report will consider the most recent report submitted to Congress by the Secretary. The General must consider the latest report submitted to Congress by the Secretary. This section does not limit the Secretary's authority to make other agreements related to the Campus. "Principally benefit veterans and their families" refers to services provided under a lease or land-sharing agreement. Services provided under a lease or land-sharing agreement must benefit veterans and their families exclusively or be tailored to their specific needs, with any benefit to the general public being secondary. The Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016 ensures that services provided must exclusively benefit veterans and their families, with any revenue generation for the Department of Veterans Affairs excluded. Additionally, a prohibition on property disposal is amended to allow for authorized actions under the Act. The Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016 amends sections related to property leases and revenue generation for the Department of Veterans Affairs.
